div.head: COLE PASHA'S REPORT FOR 1904
div.p: Coles Pasha's Report is an interesting as ever, as well arranged, and happily,as outspo- ken, and as suggestive. The author's optimism never blinds him to the defects that are still to be found in the prision system, but while he is thoruoghly determined to point out its weak- nesses, and shows a courageous readiness to confess that he has at times made too roseate forecasts pf the results of legal reforms, he is no pessimist, and his annual reports have a special attraction to all who prefer 'human documents,' which reveal the personality of their author, to mere catalogues of statistics sandwiched between the dry crusts of unillu- minating comment, with whichthe Egyptian public is sometime regaled. After pointting out that the large increase in the prision population for 1904 is due to the workinf of the revised code, under which there is practically no delay when once sentence is passed, Coles Pasha notes that, in spite of legal obanges and the estab- lishment of Markaz magistrates, there are still too many prisioners awaiting trial. In his opinion the procedure followed by the police in sending on arrested persons to the Parquet without the necessary witnesses, is largely responsible for this excesssive ratio of unsentenced prisoners. the petty theif taken flagrante delicto, instead of going before the police magistrate and gettinghid sentence as in England, is first sent before the Parquet, which has to consult the Casiere Judiciarie, summon the witnesses, and name a day for the trial. The 'dossier' system may be sure and safegaurd persons who are innocent of the crime imput- ed to them, but it is an open question as to whether its slowness does not nullify the effect of its sureness. The certainty of acquittal is said by some to make prison life comparitively blithe and cheerful, but we should imagine that it must be most exasperating to be dismissed withuout a stian on your character after awaiting tril in the most palatial gaol for six weeks or so. On the other hand, the number of prisoners appealing showed a decided diminution thanks to the recent establishment of Assize Courts, which was due to the recognition of the fact that the power of appeal had been grossly abused in the past. As regaurds the periods of imprisionment and the classification of offences, it is interesting to not that while the number of prisoners whi wer confined for contraven- tions was reduced by over 50% there was a large increase of persons imprisoned for delits (misdemeanours). The increase of the prision population in 1904 is due to the increase of persons sentence to terms of from one week to three months, imprisonment, and not, as was imagined, to any increase in the number of persons sentenced to longer periods. Indeed, the number of those sentenced to periods od 6 months or a year's imprisionment, adn over bears exactly the same proportion to the prision population as in 1903,and is only 1% lower than in 1902.

The passaged in the report which deal with juvenile offenders are of such importance that they mustbe dealt with separately and we pass on to the conduct of the prisoners. A marked increase of minor prison offencews is noted for 1904, but major offences can hardly be said to have increased, and the acts of violence and murderous assults on police officials at Tourah, which at one time threatened to become unpleasently numerous, shows a most gratifying diminution which is ascribed by Coled Pasha tot he establsihment of the discipline gang, and to the fact that the convicts are now well aware that certain selected officials carry revolvers and are ready to use them if necessary. Of the 67 prisoners who escaped, 19 are still at latrege. The prison punishments lists shows a most satisfactory and continued decrease in te sentences of corpiral punishment which have fallen from 273 in 1902 to 70 during the past year. The passgaed of this report and the report of Dr. Kirton, Principal Medical Officer to the Prisons Administration, which deal with the health of the prisoneres, demand separate notice in our columns. We are glad to note that Coles Pasha pays a well-deserved tribute to the clerical staff of the administration for the care and thoroughness with which the tables accompanying the report have been prepared, and to read that the information furnished in the Egyptian Prisons Report does not now fall far short of the statistics published annually by European and Indian prison administrations.

div.head: ESPIONAGE ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER
div.p: Inhabitants in the country part of France have remarked the presence of large numbers of vendors of images and itinernt merchants generally. These persons visit the villages in detail and show marked predilection for local gossip, Such a phenomenon was observed on the eve of the war of 1870-71, and its reappearance at this moment is su=ignificant of he resumed activities of Germant. THe pedlars are no doubt spies in the pay of the German Intelligence Department. THeir business is to find out the local resources of the country and to take note of the state of feeling of the in- habitants. During the great struggle of thirty years ago the spy, primed with local knowledge played a large part in the militaryh operations. A belame of the village would often be saluted by name by a soldier wearing the Prussian uniform who has perhaps occupie some posi- tion in the counrty before the outbreak of the war, and utilised his opportunites of seeing and hearing tot the advantage of the conquerors. In view of this factm it is, perhaps, not sur- prising that the peasants should be convinced that Germany contemplated some new mischief.

On the other hand, the French are also pre- paring for the day of an heroic struggle whose proximity rests on the knees of the gods, It appears to be established that the Military Imtelligence Department is, however, a very ineffective arm of the French Etat-major. It received its death-blow at the Dreyfus trial- that singular and disquieting symptom of official rottenness. The country, disgusted at the revelations of the uses made of the secret side of the service, practically acquiesced in its abolition. Its power and duties were generally transferred to the police, who naturally are more occupied with ordinary affairs of cri- minality than with matters of politicla and military espionage. Moreover, the repression of spying and informing when carried out under organised system of Germany, is a difficult and almost impossible operation. A pedlar upon whose person is found a note- book containing general particulars about the country-side can hardly be held in prison as a spy dangerous to the national intrests.

(AL MOAYAD.)

Marshal Faizi Pasha, commander of the Ottoman troops in 8. Arabia, has advanced into the Azir. Province bound to Sana and bas defeated, the rebels. We gather from the latest telegrams dispatched from Turkish official sources, that he has completely vanquished the Arabs, who are fleeing before him. Notwithstanding the great heat which now prevails he is nearing Sand, and within a month he will have completely subdued the revolt.

The rebels have only injured themselves by revolation against their Government. They should have remained peaceful and left interference in the affairs of the administra tion and rebellion to others. We greet with great joy the victory of the troops of the exalted Government, as it is a conquest ever tribes devoid of all mind and senre. On the other hand we regret the loss of life among Moslems caused by the victory,but the Turkish Government cannot be blamed for suppressing a rebellion, and every good Moslem hopes that this movement will be the last, and that the rule of the Turkish Government over the Arabs and the other subjects of the Empire, will be prosperous and enduring.

div.head: OUR WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: USE OF POISONOUS WELLS.

Dr. Gottschlich has recently informed us that we drink water equal to the beat in the world, as far as purity is concerned. This should console those who grumble at the price they pay for these blessings, but we are afraid that many of the European and native residents of Alexandria-and these not, the poorest-are incapable of appreciating the fact that, even if you cannot get good water without paying for it, that does not justify you in supplying your neighbours with water that must necessarily be dangerous. Alexandria, before the construction of the Mahmoudieh canal, depended for its water on wells sunk in various parts of the town, nearly all of which were poisoned by sewage infiltration, and yielded a contaminated supply, which was responsible for a variety of diseases."

The Water Company has for many years past supplied the city with pure water, but none the less, many of these wells are still open, and we should imagine that their supply is more poisonous than ever. We can understand that in the case of the very poor it is rather difficult for the authorities to force them to pay for good water, by filling up these wells on which they depend, but what are we to say of the Greek or Arab bakers, who use water obtained from wells sunk under their houses, or under the street, and drawn with hand pump to mix with flour? Medical men can tell us whether the heat of a European or Arab baker's oven is capable of destroying the microbes that such water must contain in millions, polluted as it must be by infiltration from sewers and cesspools.

The Labbane quarter contains several ot these walls, which supply adjacent bakeries. Yesterday we visited one which had been sunk, not in a court or cellar, but in the middle of a street. It was sunk opposite a large and thriving Arab bakery, which used its water, and was covered when not in use. Other wise the road was usually more or less obstructed by the drawers of water from what was nothing but a pit, sunk ten or eleven feet below the surface.

On approaching the pit we noticed several men at work with picks and spades, and assumed that the Municipality had given orders to close and fill the well. But we were unable to verify our assumption, for, on approaching its mouth, we were greeted by such a horrible and pestilent odour, that we incontinently fled. A neighbouring sewer had broken into the well! That was all! Such was the sentce from which a large bakery had drawn to water for months past. Is not this a case where our sanitary authorities can inter fere 1

div.head: EGYPTIAN PRISONS.
div.p: COLES PASHA'S REPORT.
JUDICIAL.
Committals.
96,229 males and 9,990 females were committed to the several prisons compared with 97,450 males and 12,815 females committed during 1903.

The large increase (17,826) in the number of prisoners admitted, on conviction is explained by the working of the revised code. It is, however, very satisfactory to find that the number of prisoners confined in default has dropped to 18,065, and that the Irrigation and Omdebs' Courts have imprisoned many less than during either of the previous years.
Prison population.

Under the old law it often took months to execute a judgment, whereas with the revised code there is practically no delay when once sentence is passed. It is not surprising therefore that a large increase in the prison popula tion followed immediately on the promulgation of the new law (15th April). It was hoped that, when once all the arrears had been worked cff, this increase would disappear, more espe cially as the number of prisoners who undergo imprisonment in default is now comparatively small, It is disappointing, therefore, to find the year closing with a prison population of 12,399, campared with 10,627 at the close of 1903 and 9,005 at the close of 1902. The maximum number confined was 13,080 on the last day of October, and the average was 11,928 compared with 10,234 in 1903.

If we analyse this population we find 8,856 awaiting final disposal (2,897 in 1903) and 9,043 undergoing sentence (7,736 in 1903). Of the prisoners awaiting trial, 797 were reported as "at the disposal of the Parqget" (684 in 1903) and 975; "at the disposal of the Courts" (705 in 1903), 1,575 had appealed (1,499 in 1903). Bat it is satisfactory to find that of the prisoners undergoing sentence 230 only were "in default" (761 in 1903).
Commitments before trial.

Of the 22,618 prisoners (persons temporarily confined in police locks-ups are not included in this return) shown as committed before trial 8,893 or 39% were acquitted by the courts or released by the Parquet without trial; 12,312 or 54% were convicted in 1st Instance and 1,448 or 7% were awaiting disposal at the close of the year.

If we farther analyse the figures in this return we find that 4,464 of these prisoners were only disposed of after imprisonment for one month and more, and of this number (4,464) 9,188 were either acquitted or released. 214 prisoners were still undisposed of, at the close of the year, notwithstanding that they had been in confinement for upwards of 8 months. These figures (which I have included in my. report for the first time this year) are of special interest, as I am of opinion that they throw light on one of the faults in the administration of justice in Egypt, a fault which, I fear, still calls for a remedy notwithstanding the changes in the law and the establishment of markez magistrates.

The markez magistrate does not affect the question much, as in the majority of the cases dealt with by these magistrates, there is no arrest before trial. The fault lies, in my opinion, in the procedure followed by the police in rending forward arrested persons to the Parquet without, at the same time, the witnesses. A petty thief caught in flagrant délit and sentenced within twenty four hours by a police magistrate is practically unknown in Egypt. After police action, it rests with the Parquet to consult the Casier Judiciaire, sommon witnesses, etc., and appoint a day for trial All this takes time. The dossier system may be sure; it is certainly slow, and innocent persons undoubtedly occasionally suffer in consequence.
Prisoners appealing.

It will be seen that 15,474 prisoners appealed, and of this number 8,858 or 23% were acqaitted and released. The appeals of 10,569 or 70% were rejected (i.e., prisoners were not released) and 1,547 were pending at the close of the year. It will be seen also that 8,784 or 59% of the appeals took upwards of one month to dispose of, and of this number 1,816 were successful, the prisoners being released.

Assize Courts have been now established and the abuse of the power of appeal in Egypt has been so generally recognised that further com ment is unnecessary. The information contained in this table, dealing alone with prisoners, may. however, be of interest and serve a useful purpose. It will be of interest too, in future years, to show the working of the Assize- Courts.

div.head: TROOPS FOR THE YEMEN.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.) Port Said, Tuesday.

The French 88. Bitbeyrie has arrived from Turkey on her way to the Red Sea. She is completely fall of troops, having on board o less than 2,640 men. This makes 7,000 troops who have passed through since the beginning of the month, all of them bound for the Yemen.

div.head: THE PRESIDENTE SARMIENTO.
div.p: The Argentine sloop-ship Presidente Barmiento left for Algiers, and other ports on her homeward voyage to-day. The selection given by her band. last evening attracted considerable numbers and proved most suc cessful.

div.head: THE SUNKEN DREDGER.
div.p: The preparations for raising the sucker dredger Pharaon II. are bearing completion. They include the bolting together of four pairs of large iron lighters, deek to deck. From the bottom of the upper ones of each pair, two large tubes resembling ship fannels stand out. These doubled lighters will be suuk on either side of the dredger and then, after being firmly secured to her and to each other, will be pumped out by means of hoses led down the funnels, the tops of which will bo some few feet above water level The experiments in filling and pamping out which have lately. been carried out, have proved successful, and a few days hence will see the removal of the Pharaon II.

div.head: COLLISION IN THE CANAL
div.p: A slight collision occurred last night between the City of Benares and the Adamastor, a new Portuguese cruiser. The Tatter vessel was tied up at kil. 24, and neither ship sustained much damage. The Adamastor is to leave here on Friday. She is a vessel of 1,750 tons, was built at Leghorn, and steam 17.5 knots.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The London papers, atate that Lord and Lady Cromer are not likely to return to Cairo this year till the beginning of November.
Barl Selborne, High Commissioner for British South Africa, has accepted the presidency of the Bible Society's Auxiliary at Johannesburg, where he taking the chair at a meeting to-day.
The Marquis Salvago-Raggi will probably leave by the Rabattino boat on the 10th inst.
Miralai Hopkinson Bey will return to Egypt on or about November 18.
Two and half months' leave of absence has been granted to Mr. R. E Monteith-Smith, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior,
Mr. G. H. Charman, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, goes on leave to-day and will resume duty on November 23.
Mr. G. de Besupuis, manager of the Alexandria branch of the Banco di Roma, bas returned to Alexandria. We congratulate Mr. de Beaupuis on his, recovery from his recent serious illness.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at the Deaconesses' Hospital, Alexandria, on Monday night, of Mrs. Mary Ann Talbot, wife of Mr.Wm. Talbot, in charge of the Mex lighthouses. Mrs. Talbot succumbed to heart disease, after having been in feeble health for some time past.
